Next, describe the **spatial position of subjects and elements in the video**, if relevant. Finally, describe the **camera’s height relative to the subject**, if relevant. Indicate whether the camera is positioned at the subject's height, above them, or below them. We already have this information provided at the end. If it’s not provided, try to describe it by yourself.

If **shot size or spatial position** changes, describe how these transitions occur clearly, specifying both the **initial and final states**.

In addition, the human-written captions below already describe the subjects (if any) and the scenery in this video but do not capture their spatial composition and movements. Use these captions as a reference, but do not rely on them completely. Your goal is to fully capture the spatial framing and movements in this video. Human-Written Description for Scenery: **The video is set indoors within a completely dark space, possibly a studio or stage. A single spotlight shines down from above, creating a distinct circle of light on the dark floor. Within this illuminated area, a white chalk outline resembling the shape of a body is positioned in front of a simple wooden stool, at the middle bottom of the frame. A person sits on the stool, facing forward, largely obscured in silhouette due to the strong backlighting from the spotlight. Hints of color and pattern are visible on the person's shirt, contrasted with dark pants. Their hands rest on their knees with palms facing upwards. The surrounding environment outside the spotlight remains in deep shadow.**

Please note that the video features **salient human subjects**, so you should focus on describing the spatial framing and movements of them.
